an3.88:1.1.pli: “Sādhikamidaṃ, bhikkhave, diyaḍḍhasikkhāpadasataṃ anvaddhamāsaṃ uddesaṃ āgacchati yattha attakāmā kulaputtā sikkhanti.
an3.88:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, each fortnight over a hundred and fifty training rules come up for recitation, in which gentlemen who desire self-knowledge train.

an3.88:1.2.pli: Tisso imā, bhikkhave, sikkhā yatthetaṃ sabbaṃ samodhānaṃ gacchati.
an3.88:1.2.eng: These are all included in the three trainings.

an3.88:1.4.eng: The training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.88:1.5.pli: imā kho, bhikkhave, tisso sikkhā yatthetaṃ sabbaṃ samodhānaṃ gacchati.
an3.88:1.5.eng: These are the three trainings that include them all.

an3.88:2.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti samādhismiṃ paripūrakārī paññāya paripūrakārī.
an3.88:2.1.eng: Take the case of a mendicant who has fulfilled their ethics, immersion, and wisdom.

an3.88:2.2.pli: So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi.
an3.88:2.2.eng: They break some lesser and minor training rules, but are restored.

an3.88:2.4.pli: Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttā.
an3.88:2.4.eng: Because I don’t say they’re incapable of that.

an3.88:2.5.pli: Yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariyasāruppāni tattha dhuvasīlo ca hoti ṭhitasīlo ca, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.88:2.5.eng: But they’re constant and steady in their precepts regarding the training rules that are fundamental, befitting the spiritual path. They keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.88:2.6.pli: So āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an3.88:2.6.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an3.88:2.7.pli: Taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhaṃ pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā antarāparinibbāyī hoti.
an3.88:2.7.eng: If they don’t penetrate so far, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished between one life and the next.

an3.88:2.8.pli: Taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhaṃ pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā upahaccaparinibbāyī hoti.
an3.88:2.8.eng: If they don’t penetrate so far, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished upon landing.

an3.88:2.9.pli: Taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhaṃ pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an3.88:2.9.eng: If they don’t penetrate so far, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished without extra effort.

an3.88:2.10.pli: Taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhaṃ pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an3.88:2.10.eng: If they don’t penetrate so far, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished with extra effort.

an3.88:2.11.pli: Taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhaṃ pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā uddhaṃsoto hoti akaniṭṭhagāmī.
an3.88:2.11.eng: If they don’t penetrate so far, with the ending of the five lower fetters they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.

an3.88:2.12.pli: Taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhaṃ tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā, rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an3.88:2.12.eng: If they don’t penetrate so far, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, they’re a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

an3.88:2.13.pli: Taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhaṃ tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā ekabījī hoti, ekaṃyeva mānusakaṃ bhavaṃ nibbattetvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an3.88:2.13.eng: If they don’t penetrate so far, with the ending of three fetters, they’re a one-seeder. They will be reborn just one time in a human existence, then make an end of suffering.

an3.88:2.14.pli: Taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhaṃ tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā kolaṅkolo hoti, dve vā tīṇi vā kulāni sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an3.88:2.14.eng: If they don’t penetrate so far, with the ending of three fetters, they go from family to family. They will transmigrate between two or three families and then make an end of suffering.

an3.88:2.15.pli: Taṃ vā pana anabhisambhavaṃ appaṭivijjhaṃ tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sattakkhattuparamo hoti, sattakkhattuparamaṃ deve ca manusse ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an3.88:2.15.eng: If they don’t penetrate so far, with the ending of three fetters, they have at most seven rebirths. They will transmigrate at most seven times among gods and humans and then make an end of suffering.

an3.88:3.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, paripūraṃ paripūrakārī ārādheti padesaṃ padesakārī.
an3.88:3.1.eng: So, mendicants, if you practice fully you succeed fully. If you practice partially you succeed partially.

an3.88:3.2.eng: But in any case, these training rules are not a waste, I say.”

an3.89:1.3.eng: The training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.89:2.1.eng: And what is the training in the higher ethics?

an3.89:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.89:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.89:2.3.eng: This is called the training in the higher ethics.

an3.89:3.1.eng: And what is the training in the higher mind?

an3.89:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an3.89:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.

an3.89:3.3.eng: This is called the training in the higher mind.

an3.89:4.1.eng: And what is the training in the higher wisdom?

an3.89:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an3.89:4.2.eng: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an3.89:4.3.eng: This is called the training in the higher wisdom.

an3.9:1.1.pli: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an3.9:1.1.eng: “When a foolish, incompetent, untrue person has three qualities they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.

an3.9:1.3.eng: Bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.9:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an3.9:1.4.eng: When a foolish, incompetent untrue person possesses these three qualities they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they create much wickedness.

an3.9:2.1.pli: Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṃ anupahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca puññaṃ pasavati.
an3.9:2.1.eng: When an astute, competent true person has three qualities they keep themselves intact and unscathed. They don’t deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much merit.

an3.9:2.3.eng: Good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.9:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṃ anupahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca puññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
an3.9:2.4.eng: When an astute, competent true person possesses these three qualities they keep themselves healthy and whole. They don’t deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they create much merit.”

an3.90:1.3.eng: The training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.90:2.1.eng: And what is the training in the higher ethics?

an3.90:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.90:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.90:2.3.eng: This is called the training in the higher ethics.

an3.90:3.1.eng: And what is the training in the higher mind?

an3.90:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an3.90:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.

an3.90:3.3.eng: This is called the training in the higher mind.

an3.90:4.1.eng: And what is the training in the higher wisdom?

an3.90:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an3.90:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an3.90:4.3.eng: This is called the training in the higher wisdom.

an3.90:5.1.eng: The higher ethics, the higher mind,

an3.90:5.2.eng: and the higher wisdom should be practiced

an3.90:5.3.eng: by those energetic, steadfast, and resolute,

an3.90:5.4.eng: practicing absorption, mindful, with guarded senses.

an3.90:7.1.eng: As by day, so by night;

an3.90:7.2.eng: as by night, so by day.

an3.90:8.1.eng: they call them a ‘trainee on the path’,

an3.90:8.3.eng: But a wise one who has gone to the end of the path

an3.90:8.4.eng: they call a ‘Buddha’ in the world.

an3.90:9.2.eng: freed by the ending of craving,

an3.90:9.4.eng: is like a lamp going out.”

an3.91:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena saṅkavā nāma kosalānaṃ nigamo tadavasari.
an3.91:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. He arrived at a town of the Kosalans named Paṅkadhā,

an3.91:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kassapagotto nāma bhikkhu saṅkavāyaṃ āvāsiko hoti.
an3.91:1.3.eng: Now, at that time a monk named Kassapagotta was resident at Paṅkadhā.

an3.91:1.4.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya bhikkhū sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
an3.91:1.4.eng: There the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about the training rules.

an3.91:1.5.pli: Atha kho kassapagottassa bhikkhuno bhagavati sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya bhikkhū sandassente samādapente samuttejente sampahaṃsente ahudeva akkhanti ahu appaccayo:
an3.91:1.5.eng: Kassapagotta became quite impatient and bitter, thinking,

an3.91:1.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā saṅkavāyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena rājagahaṃ tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
an3.91:1.7.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in Paṅkadhā as long as he pleased, he set out for Rājagaha.

an3.91:1.8.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena rājagahaṃ tadavasari.
an3.91:1.8.eng: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Rājagaha,

an3.91:2.1.pli: Atha kho kassapagottassa bhikkhuno acirapakkantassa bhagavato ahudeva kukkuccaṃ ahu vippaṭisāro:
an3.91:2.1.eng: Soon after the Buddha left, Kassapagotta became quite remorseful and regretful, thinking,

an3.91:2.2.pli: “alābhā vata me, na vata me lābhā; dulladdhaṃ vata me, na vata me suladdhaṃ;

an3.91:2.3.pli: yassa me bhagavati sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya bhikkhū sandassente samādapente samuttejente sampahaṃsente ahudeva akkhanti ahu appaccayo:
an3.91:2.3.eng: that when the Buddha was talking about the training rules I became quite impatient and bitter, thinking

an3.91:2.5.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato santike accayaṃ accayato deseyyan”ti.
an3.91:2.5.eng: Why don’t I go to the Buddha and confess my mistake to him?”

an3.91:2.6.pli: Atha kho kassapagotto bhikkhu senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena rājagahaṃ tena pakkāmi.
an3.91:2.6.eng: Then Kassapagotta set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Rājagaha.

an3.91:2.7.pli: Anupubbena yena rājagahaṃ yena gijjhakūṭo pabbato yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kassapagotto bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.91:2.7.eng: Eventually he came to Rājagaha and the Vulture’s Peak. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, saying:

an3.91:3.1.pli: “Ekamidaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ bhagavā saṅkavāyaṃ viharati, saṅkavā nāma kosalānaṃ nigamo.

an3.91:3.2.pli: Tatra, bhante, bhagavā sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya bhikkhū sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.

an3.91:3.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ bhagavati sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya bhikkhū sandassente samādapente samuttejente sampahaṃsente ahudeva akkhanti ahu appaccayo:

an3.91:3.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā saṅkavāyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena rājagahaṃ tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi. (…)

an3.91:3.6.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, acirapakkantassa bhagavato ahudeva kukkuccaṃ ahu vippaṭisāro:

an3.91:3.7.pli: ‘alābhā vata me, na vata me lābhā; dulladdhaṃ vata me, na vata me suladdhaṃ;

an3.91:3.8.pli: yassa me bhagavati sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya bhikkhū sandassente samādapente samuttejente sampahaṃsente ahudeva akkhanti ahu appaccayo:

an3.91:3.10.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato santike accayaṃ accayato deseyyan’ti.

an3.91:3.11.pli: Accayo maṃ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ yassa me bhagavati sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya bhikkhū sandassente samādapente samuttejente sampahaṃsente ahudeva akkhanti ahu appaccayo:
an3.91:3.11.eng: “I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to become impatient and bitter when the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about the training rules, and to think,

an3.91:3.13.pli: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṃ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu, āyatiṃ saṃvarāyā”ti.
an3.91:3.13.eng: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”

an3.91:4.1.pli: “Taggha taṃ, kassapa, accayo accagamā yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yassa te mayi sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya bhikkhū sandassente samādapente samuttejente sampahaṃsente ahudeva akkhanti ahu appaccayo:

an3.91:4.3.pli: Yato ca kho tvaṃ, kassapa, accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikarosi, taṃ te mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma.
an3.91:4.3.eng: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.

an3.91:4.4.pli: Vuddhihesā, kassapa, ariyassa vinaye yo accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikaroti, āyatiṃ saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an3.91:4.4.eng: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.

an3.91:5.1.pli: Thero cepi, kassapa, bhikkhu hoti na sikkhākāmo na sikkhāsamādānassa vaṇṇavādī, ye caññe bhikkhū na sikkhākāmā te ca na sikkhāya samādapeti, ye caññe bhikkhū sikkhākāmā tesañca na vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇati bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, evarūpassāhaṃ, kassapa, therassa bhikkhuno na vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇāmi.
an3.91:5.1.eng: Kassapa, take the case of a senior mendicant who doesn’t want to train and doesn’t praise taking up the training. They don’t encourage other mendicants who don’t want to train to take up the training. And they don’t truthfully and correctly praise at the right time those mendicants who do want to train. I don’t praise that kind of senior mendicant.

an3.91:5.3.pli: Satthā hissa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇatīti aññe naṃ bhikkhū bhajeyyuṃ, ye naṃ bhajeyyuṃ tyāssa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjeyyuṃ, yyāssa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjeyyuṃ tesaṃ taṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyāti.
an3.91:5.3.eng: Because, hearing that I praised that mendicant, other mendicants might want to keep company with them. Then they might follow their example, which would be for their lasting harm and suffering.

an3.91:5.4.pli: Tasmāhaṃ, kassapa, evarūpassa therassa bhikkhuno na vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇāmi.
an3.91:5.4.eng: That’s why I don’t praise that kind of senior mendicant.

an3.91:6.1.eng: Take the case of a middle mendicant who doesn’t want to train …

an3.91:6.2.pli: navo cepi, kassapa, bhikkhu hoti na sikkhākāmo na sikkhāsamādānassa vaṇṇavādī, ye caññe bhikkhū na sikkhākāmā te ca na sikkhāya samādapeti, ye caññe bhikkhū sikkhākāmā tesañca na vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇati bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, evarūpassāhaṃ, kassapa, navassa bhikkhuno na vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇāmi.
an3.91:6.2.eng: Take the case of a junior mendicant who doesn’t want to train …

an3.91:6.4.pli: Satthā hissa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇatīti aññe naṃ bhikkhū bhajeyyuṃ, ye naṃ bhajeyyuṃ tyāssa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjeyyuṃ, yyāssa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjeyyuṃ tesaṃ taṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyāti.

an3.91:6.5.pli: Tasmāhaṃ, kassapa, evarūpassa navassa bhikkhuno na vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇāmi.
an3.91:6.5.eng: That’s why I don’t praise that kind of junior mendicant.

an3.91:7.1.pli: Thero cepi, kassapa, bhikkhu hoti sikkhākāmo sikkhāsamādānassa vaṇṇavādī, ye caññe bhikkhū na sikkhākāmā te ca sikkhāya samādapeti, ye caññe bhikkhū sikkhākāmā tesañca vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇati bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, evarūpassāhaṃ, kassapa, therassa bhikkhuno vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇāmi.
an3.91:7.1.eng: Kassapa, take the case of a senior mendicant who does want to train and praises taking up the training. They encourage other mendicants who don’t want to train to take up the training. And they truthfully and correctly praise at the right time those mendicants who do want to train. I praise that kind of senior mendicant.

an3.91:7.3.pli: Satthā hissa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇatīti aññe naṃ bhikkhū bhajeyyuṃ, ye naṃ bhajeyyuṃ tyāssa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjeyyuṃ, yyāssa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjeyyuṃ tesaṃ taṃ assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyāti.
an3.91:7.3.eng: Because, hearing that I praised that mendicant, other mendicants might want to keep company with them. Then they might follow their example, which would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.

an3.91:7.4.pli: Tasmāhaṃ, kassapa, evarūpassa therassa bhikkhuno vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇāmi.
an3.91:7.4.eng: That’s why I praise that kind of senior mendicant.

an3.91:8.1.pli: Majjhimo cepi, kassapa, bhikkhu hoti sikkhākāmo …pe…
an3.91:8.1.eng: Take the case of a middle mendicant who wants to train …

an3.91:8.2.pli: navo cepi, kassapa, bhikkhu hoti sikkhākāmo sikkhāsamādānassa vaṇṇavādī, ye caññe bhikkhū na sikkhākāmā te ca sikkhāya samādapeti, ye caññe bhikkhū sikkhākāmā tesañca vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇati bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, evarūpassāhaṃ, kassapa, navassa bhikkhuno vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇāmi.
an3.91:8.2.eng: Take the case of a junior mendicant who wants to train …

an3.91:8.4.pli: Satthā hissa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇatīti aññe naṃ bhikkhū bhajeyyuṃ, ye naṃ bhajeyyuṃ tyāssa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjeyyuṃ, yyāssa diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjeyyuṃ tesaṃ taṃ assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyāti.

an3.91:8.5.pli: Tasmāhaṃ, kassapa, evarūpassa navassa bhikkhuno vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇāmī”ti.
an3.91:8.5.eng: That’s why I praise that kind of junior mendicant.”

an3.92:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a farmer has three urgent duties.

an3.92:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kassako gahapati sīghaṃ sīghaṃ khettaṃ sukaṭṭhaṃ karoti sumatikataṃ.
an3.92:1.3.eng: A farmer swiftly makes sure the field is well ploughed and tilled.

an3.92:1.4.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ khettaṃ sukaṭṭhaṃ karitvā sumatikataṃ sīghaṃ sīghaṃ bījāni patiṭṭhāpeti.
an3.92:1.4.eng: Next they swiftly plant seeds in season.

an3.92:1.5.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ bījāni patiṭṭhāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ udakaṃ abhinetipi apanetipi.
an3.92:1.5.eng: When the time is right, they swiftly irrigate or drain the field.

an3.92:1.6.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi kassakassa gahapatissa accāyikāni karaṇīyāni.
an3.92:1.6.eng: These are the three urgent duties of a farmer.

an3.92:1.7.pli: Tassa kho taṃ, bhikkhave, kassakassa gahapatissa natthi sā iddhi vā ānubhāvo vā:
an3.92:1.7.eng: That farmer has no special power or ability to say:

an3.92:1.8.pli: ‘ajjeva me dhaññāni jāyantu, sveva gabbhīni hontu, uttarasveva paccantū’ti.
an3.92:1.8.eng: ‘Let the crops germinate today! Let them flower tomorrow! Let them ripen the day after!’

an3.92:1.9.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, hoti so samayo yaṃ tassa kassakassa gahapatissa tāni dhaññāni utupariṇāmīni jāyantipi gabbhīnipi honti paccantipi.
an3.92:1.9.eng: But there comes a time when that farmer’s crops germinate, flower, and ripen as the seasons change.

an3.92:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tīṇimāni bhikkhussa accāyikāni karaṇīyāni.
an3.92:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant has three urgent duties.

an3.92:2.3.eng: Undertaking the training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.92:2.4.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi bhikkhussa accāyikāni karaṇīyāni.
an3.92:2.4.eng: These are the three urgent duties of a mendicant.

an3.92:2.5.pli: Tassa kho taṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno natthi sā iddhi vā ānubhāvo vā:
an3.92:2.5.eng: That mendicant has no special power or ability to say:

an3.92:2.6.pli: ‘ajjeva me anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccatu sve vā uttarasve vā’ti.
an3.92:2.6.eng: ‘Let my mind be freed from defilements by not grasping today! Or tomorrow! Or the day after!’

an3.92:2.7.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, hoti so samayo yaṃ tassa bhikkhuno adhisīlampi sikkhato adhicittampi sikkhato adhipaññampi sikkhato anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccati.
an3.92:2.7.eng: But there comes a time—as that mendicant trains in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom—that their mind is freed from defilements by not grasping.

an3.92:3.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an3.92:3.2.pli: ‘tibbo no chando bhavissati adhisīlasikkhāsamādāne, tibbo chando bhavissati adhicittasikkhāsamādāne, tibbo chando bhavissati adhipaññāsikkhāsamādāne’ti.
an3.92:3.2.eng: ‘We will have keen enthusiasm for undertaking the training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.’

an3.93:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, wanderers of other religions advocate three kinds of seclusion.

an3.93:1.3.eng: Seclusion in robes, almsfood, and lodgings.

an3.93:2.1.pli: Tatridaṃ, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā cīvarapavivekasmiṃ paññāpenti, sāṇānipi dhārenti, masāṇānipi dhārenti, chavadussānipi dhārenti, paṃsukūlānipi dhārenti, tirīṭānipi dhārenti, ajinampi dhārenti, ajinakkhipampi dhārenti, kusacīrampi dhārenti, vākacīrampi dhārenti, phalakacīrampi dhārenti, kesakambalampi dhārenti, vālakambalampi dhārenti, ulūkapakkhikampi dhārenti.
an3.93:2.1.eng: Wanderers of other religions advocate this kind of seclusion in robes. They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.

an3.93:2.2.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā cīvarapavivekasmiṃ paññāpenti.
an3.93:2.2.eng: This is what wanderers of other religions advocate for seclusion in robes.

an3.93:3.1.pli: Tatridaṃ, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā piṇḍapātapavivekasmiṃ paññāpenti.
an3.93:3.1.eng: Wanderers of other religions advocate this kind of seclusion in almsfood.

an3.93:3.2.pli: Sākabhakkhāpi honti, sāmākabhakkhāpi honti, nīvārabhakkhāpi honti, daddulabhakkhāpi honti, haṭabhakkhāpi honti, kaṇabhakkhāpi honti, ācāmabhakkhāpi honti, piññākabhakkhāpi honti, tiṇabhakkhāpi honti, gomayabhakkhāpi honti, vanamūlaphalāhārā yāpenti pavattaphalabhojī.
an3.93:3.2.eng: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.

an3.93:3.3.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā piṇḍapātapavivekasmiṃ paññāpenti.
an3.93:3.3.eng: This is what the wanderers of other religions advocate for seclusion in almsfood.

an3.93:4.1.pli: Tatridaṃ, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā senāsanapavivekasmiṃ paññāpenti araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ bhusāgāraṃ.
an3.93:4.1.eng: Wanderers of other religions advocate this kind of seclusion in lodgings. They stay in a wilderness, at the root of a tree, in a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw, or a threshing-hut.

an3.93:4.2.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā senāsanapavivekasmiṃ paññāpenti.
an3.93:4.2.eng: This is what wanderers of other religions advocate for seclusion in lodgings.

an3.93:4.3.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi aññatitthiyā paribbājakā pavivekāni paññāpenti.
an3.93:4.3.eng: These are the three kinds of seclusion that wanderers of other religions advocate.

an3.93:5.1.pli: Tīṇi kho panimāni, bhikkhave, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye bhikkhuno pavivekāni.
an3.93:5.1.eng: In this teaching and training, there are three kinds of seclusion for a mendicant.

an3.93:5.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā ca hoti, dussīlyañcassa pahīnaṃ hoti, tena ca vivitto hoti;
an3.93:5.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant is ethical, giving up unethical conduct, being secluded from it.

an3.93:5.4.pli: sammādiṭṭhiko ca hoti, micchādiṭṭhi cassa pahīnā hoti, tāya ca vivitto hoti;
an3.93:5.4.eng: They have right view, giving up wrong view, being secluded from it.

an3.93:5.5.pli: khīṇāsavo ca hoti, āsavā cassa pahīnā honti, tehi ca vivitto hoti.
an3.93:5.5.eng: They’ve ended defilements, giving up defilements, being secluded from them.

an3.93:5.6.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, dussīlyañcassa pahīnaṃ hoti, tena ca vivitto hoti;
an3.93:5.6.eng: When a mendicant has these three kinds of seclusion,

an3.93:5.7.pli: sammādiṭṭhiko ca hoti, micchādiṭṭhi cassa pahīnā hoti, tāya ca vivitto hoti;

an3.93:5.8.pli: khīṇāsavo ca hoti, āsavā cassa pahīnā honti, tehi ca vivitto hoti.

an3.93:5.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu aggappatto sārappatto suddho sāre patiṭṭhito’.
an3.93:5.9.eng: they’re called a mendicant who has reached the peak and the pith, being pure and consolidated in the core.

an3.93:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kassakassa gahapatissa sampannaṃ sālikkhettaṃ.
an3.93:6.1.eng: When a farmer’s rice field is ripe,

an3.93:6.2.pli: Tamenaṃ kassako gahapati sīghaṃ sīghaṃ lavāpeyya.
an3.93:6.2.eng: they’d have the rice cut swiftly,

an3.93:6.3.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ lavāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ saṅgharāpeyya.

an3.93:6.4.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ saṅgharāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ ubbahāpeyya.

an3.93:6.5.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ ubbahāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ puñjaṃ kārāpeyya.

an3.93:6.6.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ puñjaṃ kārāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ maddāpeyya.

an3.93:6.7.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ maddāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ palālāni uddharāpeyya.

an3.93:6.8.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ palālāni uddharāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ bhusikaṃ uddharāpeyya.

an3.93:6.9.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ bhusikaṃ uddharāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ opunāpeyya.

an3.93:6.10.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ opunāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ atiharāpeyya.

an3.93:6.11.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ atiharāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ koṭṭāpeyya.

an3.93:6.12.pli: Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ koṭṭāpetvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ thusāni uddharāpeyya.
an3.93:6.12.eng: and have the husks removed swiftly.

an3.93:6.13.pli: Evamassu tāni, bhikkhave, kassakassa gahapatissa dhaññāni aggappattāni sārappattāni suddhāni sāre patiṭṭhitāni.
an3.93:6.13.eng: In this way that farmer’s crop would reach the peak and the pith, being pure and consolidated in the core.

an3.93:7.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yato bhikkhu sīlavā ca hoti, dussīlyañcassa pahīnaṃ hoti, tena ca vivitto hoti;
an3.93:7.1.eng: In the same way, when a mendicant is ethical, giving up unethical conduct, being secluded from it;

an3.93:7.2.pli: sammādiṭṭhiko ca hoti, micchādiṭṭhi cassa pahīnā hoti, tāya ca vivitto hoti;
an3.93:7.2.eng: when they have right view, giving up wrong view, being secluded from it;

an3.93:7.3.pli: khīṇāsavo ca hoti, āsavā cassa pahīnā honti, tehi ca vivitto hoti.
an3.93:7.3.eng: when they’ve ended defilements, giving up defilements, being secluded from them:

an3.93:7.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu aggappatto sārappatto suddho sāre patiṭṭhito’”ti.
an3.93:7.4.eng: they’re called a mendicant who has reached the peak and the pith, being pure and consolidated in the core.”

an3.94:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, saradasamaye viddhe vigatavalāhake deve ādicco nabhaṃ abbhussakkamāno sabbaṃ ākāsagataṃ tamagataṃ abhivihacca bhāsate ca tapate ca virocati ca.
an3.94:1.1.eng: “In the autumn, the heavens are sunny and cloudless. And as the sun is rising to the firmament, having dispelled all the darkness of space, it shines and glows and radiates.

an3.94:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yato ariyasāvakassa virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ uppajjati, saha dassanuppādā, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa tīṇi saṃyojanāni pahīyanti—
an3.94:2.1.eng: In the same way, when the stainless, immaculate vision of the teaching arises in a noble disciple, three fetters are given up:

an3.94:2.2.eng: substantialist view, doubt, and misapprehension of precepts and observances.

an3.94:3.1.pli: Athāparaṃ dvīhi dhammehi niyyāti abhijjhāya ca byāpādena ca.
an3.94:3.1.eng: Afterwards they get rid of two things: covetousness and ill will.

an3.94:3.2.pli: So vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an3.94:3.2.eng: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an3.94:3.3.pli: Tasmiñce, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako kālaṃ kareyya, natthi taṃ saṃyojanaṃ yena saṃyojanena saṃyutto ariyasāvako puna imaṃ lokaṃ āgaccheyyā”ti.
an3.94:3.3.eng: If that noble disciple passed away at that time, they’re bound by no fetter that might return them to this world.”
